comments.commentBody: I went to undergraduate school twice, once in the 70s and once in the early 00s.  The first time, my observation was that slackers cheated.  The second time, I observed top-ranked, award-winning students cheating because "they didn't have enough time to do all the work." The students I encountered during my second program, though, were far more intellectually engaged and more focused.   So I think a greater proportion of students today truly wish to excel, but also sometimes confuse genuine achievement with superficial recognition.
You've just figured this out?  At least one of them isn't built totaly on lies.

Its a culmination of a long campaign season where differences become starker. We Americans have become such zombies in an ADHD world, Kevin, that yes infomercials and advertisements are the only things that can catch and keep our attention. Think of each delegate, who is giving his/her time to attend this convention, it is their civic duty and they are rewarded for being politically active, (nothing wrong in being an arm chair commentators, BTW).

This grand insight must come with the sad recognition that the Democratic convention will introduce no big new ideas, and will shy away from issues of jobs and 3 1/2 years of abysmally failed Democratic stewardship of the economy; to focus merely on the fear that can be ginned up by vice-president Biden's prospect of a re-enslavement of African Americans by Republicans.

Yeah, I know. It's tough to say something relevant when you really have nothing to say that's relevant.

But, then, Ryan, Condi and Marco Rubio really smoked at the OTHER convention, didn't they? So, they may be infomercials, but when you actually have something to say, they can at least be entertaining.
The conventions are nothing more than glorified infomercials.
I got ya' one better.  Corn is fed to cows to fatten them up for slaughter.  How can we expect any other result when we feed ourselves corn, and corn products.

More could be done by simply eliminating the lunch tray!

Not, in my opinion, a well thought out comment.

100% behind the Bloomberg administration on this one. Food  insecurity is more about deficiencies and cheap calories than total calorie intake in NYC so it's increadible that a good policy where breakfast is still provided and students get a lean lunch could be decried. It's the right direction and more should be done.

You're hurting something serious Rickie. It's all over every post you've dropped in this thread. I'm betting you'll leave Oregon after Obama beats Romney with the elctoral votes that Oregon adds to his overall total. Don't worry though, Arizona will take you with open arms.

A minority of senior faculty at elite schools and research universities make six figure salaries, and many of them, particularly in the sciences, pull in grants much bigger than their salaries that keep those universities afloat.  Increasing percentages of college professors are adjunct, part=time, or on limited-term appointments;  some of those teach several classes on several campuses and still make under $20,000 a year--this is after studying for 5-8-10 years to get their Ph.D.s.   So don't blame the faculty for the high cost of education.   Most of us don't teach in the Ivy League, and most students don't go there either.
Michelle gave the true keynote speech. Wow!

It was a great speech, although I can't overlook the fact that she was speaking about our fundamental rights despite the fact that her husband abolished Habeas Corpus, and then fought Habeas Corpus' defenders in court.

She's very personable, and genuinely feels what she was saying, but still... her husband has amassed an appalling policy record in some areas (the environment in particular), and she has no political record of her own. It should be obvious by now that if Barack Obama had had a political record in 2008, he would not be President today. I will never again trust another candidate with no record.

And all those feelings aside, I really am uncomfortable with the tendency toward family dynasties, be they Clintons. Bush's or Obama's This is supposed to be a Republic, not a late-stage Republic decaying into a hereditary royalty.

Kate Middleton is your example of a hard-working women? Ha, you've lost ALL credibility it seems!

Kate Middleton is a women who is herself - alongside her husband and his family - not democratically elected by the people (sorry us 'commoners' as we're referred to by the 'royalty') of the country, but by the notion that her husband and his family (and indeed thus their future children), are born of more 'noble and pure' blood than us actual citizens of said country. Moreover, she has done NOTHING for the country, other than use our taxes to pay for her ALWAYS privileged lifestyle, and attend charity galas and award shows in a pretence that she is thus 'helping others'.

In Michelle Obama, you at least have a First-Lady whose husband you freely elected, who herself came from honest and humble lower/middle-class beginnings, and who then worked hard to achieve what she has done in life (including her initiatives for the families of the armed forces). With Kate Middleton however, you have a spoilt rich girl who married into an inherently archaic, elitist and racist system of 'monarchy', and has done nothing since.

And indeed, at least with Michelle Obama, you have an opportunity to freely vote President Obama out of office should your country decide in November to do so, whereas we in Britain are stuck with the mooch that is Kate Middleton for the rest of our taxpaying lives!

"And note: the Democrats are only talking about private-sector jobs. States, cities and localities have cut hundreds of thousands of public sector jobs in recent years to balance their budgets."

Well, sheesh, the Republicans don't want you to know that the recoveries from the Reagan and Bush recessions were greatly aided by increases in public sector jobs, whereas Pres. Obama's numbers have have been penalized by states' belt-tightening measures. Paul Krugman has pointed this out very clearly. Don't other NYTimes writers read Krugman's columns?

I just want to thank Michelle for giving such an honest, heartfelt accounting for why we all need to work towards, to get her husband re-elected president. I just wished she begged people, that if they are going to vote for Barrack, please god may they not vote for any republican at any level from dog catcher to senate. Otherwise you'd just be throwing your votes away and consigning all of us to at least four more years of do nothing know nothingism at the very time in history where we actually need some leaders to move things forward.

Do we really want a man who's got the nickname outsourcing pioneer, as the man who's suppose to correct this very problem?

Just one of the ways he made his millions at the expense of American citizens, then stashed the cash he made from these schemes in off shore accounts.

Very good article in rolling stone magazine's latest edition about the great out sourcer. The term vulture capitalist, is a very worthy and appropriate term for the strategy they use to amass their wealth.

It has nothing to do with job creation. which the article is very good at explaining why. Must reading for any responsible voter.
It's all about creating jobs here.  And frankly, the Republicans' tired "trickle down" and "cut taxes" mindset has nothing to do with rebuilding an infrastructure of jobs in the USA.
oh, i know this story well - "auntie mame" by patrick dennis.  and ctp, you're absolutely right - "ghastly"
What a shame that the Times doesn't seem to be reporting on the Paralympics.  The athletes' achievements are inspirational for all of us.
I think Josh George is one of the greatest wheelchair athletes out there. Keep working hard and kick some butt Josh!

Agreed. Wow and wow.

(Ari Fletscher can take his passive-aggressive partisan digs and bury them).

That is simply untrue. The Democrats did not tell lies about Republican, they stressed what they will do for the country, for individuals of all kinds. Amy, you must have been watching something other than the convention tonight.
It's the Republicans who did the trashing. The Democrats understand that people want to see something positive and reassuring about the future and that is what the Democrats showed the country tonight.
Which is easy when you say nothing of substance.

Two people with MS.  Michelle's Dad kept going to work.  Ms. Romney uses horse therapy.  One disease, two perspectives of dealing with adversity.   Which one would I trust?  Who has the higher standards?  Most assuredly it is not the GOP who really does not think for themselves.   What you saw tonight were people who had help, who moved up the ladder, and who did not base their whole lives on putting political party first and country second.  Your standards are based on what you have been fed....I would have none of it.

So you're not going to vote because you're paying a higher price for gas than you think you should. So are others out here, but really?
Not go to the polls to vote? Your ancestors have struggled to have a free country - one in which you and every other American ( not felons) have the liberty to vote and you won't do it? I wouldn't brag about that if I were you.
Think about that the next time you pump your gas.
I'd rather live in a world where we strive to make America as comfortable as a country club rather than as difficult as Chicago's south side.
It took 8 years Unser Bush to ruin the economy.  President Obama deserves  the opportunity to finish his repairs.  Romney would do  take is back to robber baron hood.

Carolyn, were you watching the convention tonight? There were many examples of how the Affordable Care Act is benefiting real people - and many other examples of the president's initiatives. There is also a website that explains how it all works. http://www.whitehouse.gov/healthreform

Don't let propaganda and negative ads confuse you. The economy is still recovering from being on the brink of implosion 4 years ago. The president's policies have actually helped some - and would have helped more if the Republicans hadn't blocked much of what he wanted to do (they gambled that keeping the economy weak was their best shot at defeating him).

There is a huge difference in the parties and the future will depend on who wins - not just president but Congress and local elections, too.

It took 12 years to come out of the Great Depression. McCain could have done no better, nor Romney - tho it is easy for him to say so without having to back it up - nor, much of ANYTHING Romney says.

I make no apologies for President Obama. Just realistic expectations and how entrenched partisan politics are in Washington, and yes, he was somewhat naive to think he could change that.

He has learned. He is wiser. And he is STILL the man of far greater character and honesty.

You mean the economy the GOP did everything in their power to keep from improving so they could pin the blame on Obama and hurt his reelection?

I'll keep that in mind when I vote as I'm sure millions of other informed Americans will as well.
